elements.content: Porous Cu−Cd mixed-metal−organic frameworks [{Cd(NO3)2}2{(Cu(Pyac)2}3] (M‘MOF 1) and [{CdCl2}{Cu(Pyac)2}2] (M‘MOF 2) {Cu(Pyac)2 = bis[3-(4-pyridyl)pentane-2,4-dionato]copper(II)} have been synthesized by the reaction of Cu(Pyac)2 with Cd(NO3)2 and CdCl2. They are noninterpenetrating 1D ladder and 2D square-grid frameworks, constructed from Cu(Pyac)2 building blocks with T-shaped Cd(NO3)2 nodes and square-planar CdCl2 nodes, respectively. The 1D ladders and 2D square grids are stacked in ABCABC... and ABCDEF... packings, leading to 2D interconnected channels of ca. 5.7 × 10.2 and 4.1 × 9.8 Å in 1 and 1D channels of ca. 8.0 × 8.2 Å in 2, respectively. The copper sites in these two M‘MOFs are coordinated by solvent molecules and exposed to the pores.
elements.clean_text: Porous Cu-Cd mixed-metal-organic frameworks [{Cd(NO3)2}2{(Cu(Pyac)2}3] (M‘MOF 1) and [{CdCl2}{Cu(Pyac)2}2] (M‘MOF 2) {Cu(Pyac)2 = bis[3-(4-pyridyl)pentane-2,4-dionato]copper(II)} have been synthesized by the reaction of Cu(Pyac)2 with Cd(NO3)2 and CdCl2. They are noninterpenetrating 1D ladder and 2D square-grid frameworks, constructed from Cu(Pyac)2 building blocks with T-shaped Cd(NO3)2 nodes and square-planar CdCl2 nodes, respectively. The 1D ladders and 2D square grids are stacked in ABCABC... and ABCDEF... packings, leading to 2D interconnected channels of ca. 5.7 × 10.2 and 4.1 × 9.8 Å in 1 and 1D channels of ca. 8.0 × 8.2 Å in 2, respectively. The copper sites in these two M‘MOFs are coordinated by solvent molecules and exposed to the pores.

elements.content: Reactions of bis[3-(4-pyridyl)pentane-2,4-dionato]copper(II) [Cu(Pyac)2] with cadmium nitrate and cadmium chloride yield porous Cu−Cd mixed-metal−organic materials:  a 1D ladder framework [{Cd(NO3)2}2{(Cu(Pyac)2}3] (M‘MOF 1) and a 2D square-grid framework [{CdCl2}{Cu(Pyac)2}2] (M‘MOF 2). In both structures, unsaturated copper sites are exposed to ∼19.7-Å pores for host−guest interactions.
elements.clean_text: Reactions of bis[3-(4-pyridyl)pentane-2,4-dionato]copper(II) [Cu(Pyac)2] with cadmium nitrate and cadmium chloride yield porous Cu-Cd mixed-metal-organic materials: a 1D ladder framework [{Cd(NO3)2}2{(Cu(Pyac)2}3] (M‘MOF 1) and a 2D square-grid framework [{CdCl2}{Cu(Pyac)2}2] (M‘MOF 2). In both structures, unsaturated copper sites are exposed to ~19.7-Å pores for host-guest interactions.

elements.content: There has been extensive interest in porous metal−organic framework (MOF) materials because of their possible applications in gas storage, separation, molecular recognition, magnetism, and catalysis. One of the current challenges for synthesis of such porous MOFs is to functionalize their pores, so that they can be well-suited for specific host−guest interactions and practical applications. We believe the recently developed “preconstructed building block” approach can be useful in accomplishing this goal. In this method, metal-containing molecular complexes preconstructed from simple organic linkers combine with other metal ions to construct mixed-metal−organic frameworks (M‘MOFs). This approach provides rational design principles for incorporating unsaturated metal centers into porous mixed-metal−organic frameworks. However, this approach has not been extensively explored. Although a number of porous M‘MOFs have been reported, only a few of these materials show coordinative unsaturation at the transition-metal center.
elements.clean_text: There has been extensive interest in porous metal-organic framework (MOF) materials because of their possible applications in gas storage, separation, molecular recognition, magnetism, and catalysis. One of the current challenges for synthesis of such porous MOFs is to functionalize their pores, so that they can be well-suited for specific host-guest interactions and practical applications. We believe the recently developed "preconstructed building block" approach can be useful in accomplishing this goal. In this method, metal-containing molecular complexes preconstructed from simple organic linkers combine with other metal ions to construct mixed-metal-organic frameworks (M‘MOFs). This approach provides rational design principles for incorporating unsaturated metal centers into porous mixed-metal-organic frameworks. However, this approach has not been extensively explored. Although a number of porous M‘MOFs have been reported, only a few of these materials show coordinative unsaturation at the transition-metal center.

elements.content: We have been interested in porous supramolecular metal β-diketonates for their host−guest chemistry. For the successful preparation of porous M‘MOFs based on metal β-diketonate moieties to be ensured, these moieties must contain donor groups capable of binding to the M‘ metal atoms. We chose Cu(Pyac)2 {i.e., bis[3-(4-pyridyl)pentane-2,4-dionato]copper(II); see Scheme } as the preconstructed building block for this purpose. As an expanded 4,4‘-bipyridine analogue, Cu(Pyac)2 contains both Lewis-base N atoms and Lewis-acid Cu sites. We expected that Cu(Pyac)2 would yield porous M‘MOFs upon reaction with metal nodes of various geometries. We now report that the reactions of Cu(Pyac)2 with Cd(NO3)2 and CdCl2, acting as T-shaped and square-planar nodes, respectively, produce 1D and 2D porous M‘MOFs; see Scheme . M‘MOF 1 is a 1D ladder framework with the repeating unit [{Cd(NO3)2}2{Cu(Pyac)2}3], and M‘MOF 2 is a 2D square-grid framework containing [{CdCl2}{Cu(Pyac)2}2].
elements.clean_text: We have been interested in porous supramolecular metal β-diketonates for their host-guest chemistry. For the successful preparation of porous M‘MOFs based on metal β-diketonate moieties to be ensured, these moieties must contain donor groups capable of binding to the M‘ metal atoms. We chose Cu(Pyac)2 {i.e., bis[3-(4-pyridyl)pentane-2,4-dionato]copper(II); see Scheme } as the preconstructed building block for this purpose. As an expanded 4,4‘-bipyridine analogue, Cu(Pyac)2 contains both Lewis-base N atoms and Lewis-acid Cu sites. We expected that Cu(Pyac)2 would yield porous M‘MOFs upon reaction with metal nodes  of various geometries. We now report that the reactions of Cu(Pyac)2 with Cd(NO3)2 and CdCl2, acting as T-shaped and square-planar nodes, respectively, produce 1D and 2D porous M‘MOFs; see Scheme . M‘MOF 1 is a 1D ladder framework with the repeating unit [{Cd(NO3)2}2{Cu(Pyac)2}3], and M‘MOF 2 is a 2D square-grid framework containing [{CdCl2}{Cu(Pyac)2}2].

elements.content: Cu(Pyac)2 Reacts with Cd(NO3)2 to Make the 1D Ladder-Type M‘MOF 1 and with CdCl2 to Make the 2D Square-grid M‘MOF 2.
elements.clean_text: 1  Cu(Pyac)2 Reacts with Cd(NO3)2 to Make the 1D Ladder-Type M‘MOF 1 and with CdCl2 to Make the 2D Square-grid M‘MOF 2.

elements.content: Crystalline 1 was obtained in 60% yield over a period of 2 days by layering a MeOH solution (8 mL) of Cd(NO3)2·4H2O (70.0 mg, 0.227 mmol) onto a THF solution (8 mL) of Cu(Pyac)2 (14.0 mg, 0.028 mmol27). Similarly, 2 was prepared in 63% yield by layering a THF solution (8 mL) of Cu(Pyac)2 (17.6 mg, 0.036 mmol) onto an aqueous solution (8 mL) of CdCl2·2.5H2O (224 mg, 0.98 mmol).
elements.clean_text: Crystalline 1 was obtained in 60% yield over a period of 2 days by layering a MeOH solution (8 mL) of Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (70.0 mg, 0.227 mmol) onto a THF solution (8 mL) of Cu(Pyac)2 (14.0 mg, 0.028 mmol27). Similarly, 2 was prepared in 63% yield by layering a THF solution (8 mL) of Cu(Pyac)2 (17.6 mg, 0.036 mmol) onto an aqueous solution (8 mL) of CdCl2⋅2.5H2O (224 mg, 0.98 mmol).

elements.content: The crystal structure of 1 contains 1D ladders in which T-shaped Cd2+ nodes (capped by two chelating NO3 - anions) are bridged by Cu(Pyac)2 building blocks (Figure a). The Cd···Cd distances are 19.77 and 19.65 Å for the rung and edge, respectively.
elements.clean_text: The crystal structure of 1 contains 1D ladders in which T-shaped Cd2+ nodes (capped by two chelating NO3 - anions) are bridged by Cu(Pyac)2 building blocks (Figure a). The Cd⋅⋅⋅Cd distances are 19.77 and 19.65 Å for the rung and edge, respectively.

elements.content: Views of the crystal structure of the Cd(NO3)2−Cu(Pyac)2 M‘MOF 1 (Cu atoms orange, Cd beige). (a) A portion of one 1D “ladder” unit. (b) View along the “ladder” units, showing the ABCABC... packing. (c) View approximately along the a crystallographic axis. On the left is a schematic drawing showing only the Cd atoms, to illustrate the repeating units along two adjacent ladders. The space-filling model on the right shows the channels that pass through successive layers of ladder units.
elements.clean_text: 1  Views of the crystal structure of the Cd(NO3)2-Cu(Pyac)2 M‘MOF 1 (Cu atoms orange, Cd beige). (a) A portion of one 1D "ladder" unit. (b) View along the "ladder" units, showing the ABCABC... packing. (c) View approximately along the a crystallographic axis. On the left is a schematic drawing showing only the Cd atoms, to illustrate the repeating units along two adjacent ladders. The space-filling model on the right shows the channels that pass through successive layers of ladder units.

elements.content: Other examples of 1D ladder frameworks are often interpenetrated, leading to reduced porosity. In contrast, the new Cd−Cu M‘MOF 1 is an unusual example of a 1D noninterpenetrating ladder structure, in which these 1D ladders are stacked together in ABCABC packing (Figure b). Two other types of packing for noninterpenetrating 1D ladders have been reported:  a porous ABAB packing and a nonporous herringbone packing. Our new M‘MOF 1 is the first example of a 1D ladder structure with ABCABC packing.
elements.clean_text: Other examples of 1D ladder frameworks are often interpenetrated, leading to reduced porosity. In contrast, the new Cd-Cu M‘MOF 1 is an unusual example of a 1D noninterpenetrating ladder structure, in which these 1D ladders are stacked together in ABCABC packing (Figure b). Two other types of packing for noninterpenetrating 1D ladders have been reported: a porous ABAB packing and a nonporous herringbone packing. Our new M‘MOF 1 is the first example of a 1D ladder structure with ABCABC packing.

elements.content: The pores in one 1D ladder in 1 are close to those in adjacent layers in both the a (see Figure c) and b crystallographic directions. This results in a 2D network of interconnected channels. The channels along a have dimensions of ca. 5.7 × 10.2 Å, and those along b are ca. 4.1 × 9.8 Å. The pores occupy about 60% of the crystal volume.
elements.clean_text: The pores in one 1D ladder in 1 are close to those in adjacent layers in both the a (see Figure c) and b crystallographic directions. This results in a 2D network of interconnected channels. The channels along a have dimensions of ca. 5.7 × 10.2 Å, and those along b are ca. 4.1 × 9.8 Å. The pores occupy about 60% of the crystal volume.

elements.content: The CdCl2−Cu(Pyac)2 M‘MOF 2 has a 2D square-grid structure (Figure a) in which CdCl2 units are bridged by Cu(Pyac)2 building blocks. The Cd···Cd and Cu···Cu distances are 19.718 Å, comparable to those in 2D MOFs with large cavities. The 2D square-grid layers are stacked so as to repeat every six layers (ABCDEF... packing, Figure b). This packing leads to a channel with dimensions of ca. 8.0 × 8.2 Å (Figure c). The porosity of M‘MOF 2 is about 63%.
elements.clean_text: The CdCl2-Cu(Pyac)2 M‘MOF 2 has a 2D square-grid structure (Figure a) in which CdCl2 units are bridged by Cu(Pyac)2 building blocks. The Cd⋅⋅⋅Cd and Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances are 19.718 Å, comparable to those in 2D MOFs with large cavities. The 2D square-grid layers are stacked  so as to repeat every six layers (ABCDEF... packing, Figure b). This packing leads to a channel with dimensions of ca. 8.0 × 8.2 Å (Figure c). The porosity of M‘MOF 2 is about 63%.

elements.content: Views of the crystal structure of the CdCl2−Cu(Pyac)2 M‘MOF 2. (a) One square-grid layer. (b) Several square-grid layers, edge-on, showing the ABCDEF... packing. (c) Space-filling model to show the approximate size of the channels.
elements.clean_text: 2  Views of the crystal structure of the CdCl2-Cu(Pyac)2 M‘MOF 2. (a) One square-grid layer. (b) Several square-grid layers, edge-on, showing the ABCDEF... packing. (c) Space-filling model to show the approximate size of the channels.

elements.content: It is of interest to note that the copper sites in these two porous M‘MOFs are accessible for host−guest interactions. Coordination of solvent molecules to the Cu sites is evident in the crystal structures of both 1 and 2; see Figure .
elements.clean_text: It is of interest to note that the copper sites in these two porous M‘MOFs are accessible for host-guest interactions. Coordination of solvent molecules to the Cu sites is evident in the crystal structures of both 1 and 2; see Figure .

elements.content: Coordinated solvent molecules in the crystal structures of (a) Cd(NO3)2−Cu(Pyac)2 M‘MOF 1 (coordinated CH3OH) and (b) CdCl2−Cu(Pyac)2 M‘MOF 2 (coordinated THF). Free (uncoordinated) solvent molecules are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 3  Coordinated solvent molecules in the crystal structures of (a) Cd(NO3)2-Cu(Pyac)2 M‘MOF 1 (coordinated CH3OH) and (b) CdCl2-Cu(Pyac)2 M‘MOF 2 (coordinated THF). Free (uncoordinated) solvent molecules are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: Crystals of M‘MOF 1 turn opaque within seconds in air, whereas those of M‘MOF 2 gradually turn opaque over a period of ca. 30 min. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) of M‘MOF 1 and 2 indicate that the solvent/guest molecules are lost over the temperature ranges of 22−67 and 22−100 °C, respectively. The desolvated frameworks are stable up to about 220 and 210 °C, respectively, and then decompose.
elements.clean_text: Crystals of M‘MOF 1 turn opaque within seconds in air, whereas those of M‘MOF 2 gradually turn opaque over a period of ca. 30 min. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) of M‘MOF 1 and 2 indicate that the solvent/guest molecules are lost over the temperature ranges of 22-67 and 22-100 °C, respectively. The desolvated frameworks are stable up to about 220 and 210 °C, respectively, and then decompose.

elements.content: Guest-binding sites in porous metal−organic frameworks are important for the development of functional properties. We have now shown that our preconstructed building block approach makes it possible to incorporate these kinds of sites into porous materials by rational crystal design principles. We are currently endeavoring to synthesize more robust porous mixed-metal−organic frameworks with guest-binding sites that will be appropriate for catalytic and sensor applications.
elements.clean_text: Guest-binding sites in porous metal-organic frameworks are important for the development of functional properties. We have now shown that our preconstructed building block approach makes it possible to incorporate these kinds of sites into porous materials by rational crystal design principles. We are currently endeavoring to synthesize more robust porous mixed-metal-organic frameworks with guest-binding sites that will be appropriate for catalytic and sensor applications.

metadata.title:
Porous Cu−Cd Mixed-Metal−Organic Frameworks Constructed from
Cu(Pyac)2 {Bis[3-(4-pyridyl)pentane-2,4-dionato]copper(II)}
